qas.question: Which timekeeping devices are the most accurate?
What method do atomic clocks use to measure seconds?

answers.text: the frequency of electronic transitions in certain atoms

qas.question: Which system bases its unit of time on the properties of caesium?
How long has the International System of Measurements based the second on caesium?
In what year were caesium atoms discovered?
What are microwaves the most accurate at doing?
What are microwaves also used to calibrate?
What system bases its unit of time on microwave properties?
How many cycles of radiation are in microwaves?
Which timekeeping devices are the least accurate?

plausible_answers.text: the frequency of electronic transitions in certain atoms

qas.question: What method do atomic clocks use to measure cycles?
Which system bases its unit of time on the properties of vibrations?
How long has the International System of Measurements based the second on years?

plausible_answers.text: as 9,192,631,770 cycles of the radiation that corresponds to the transition between two electron spin energy levels of the ground state of the 133Cs atom

qas.question: How does caesium deine the second?

context: The most accurate <b5_0>timekeeping<b5_0/> devices are <a0_0><b9_0>atomic clocks<b9_0/><a0_0/>, which are accurate to seconds in many millions of years, and are used to calibrate <b6_0>other clocks and timekeeping instruments<b6_0/>. Atomic clocks use <a1_0><b10_0>the frequency of electronic transitions in certain atoms<b10_0/><a1_0/> to measure the second. One of the most common atoms used is caesium, most modern atomic clocks probe caesium with microwaves to determine the frequency of these electron vibrations. <a3_0><b12_0>Since <b4_0>1967<b12_0/><b4_0/><a3_0/>, <a2_0><b11_0>the <b7_0>International System of Measurements<b11_0/><b7_0/><a2_0/> bases its unit of time, the second, on the properties of caesium atoms. SI defines the second <b13_0>as <b8_0>9,192,631,770 cycles<b8_0/> of the radiation that corresponds to the transition between two electron spin energy levels of the ground state of the 133Cs atom<b13_0/>.
